channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jobs Report Withheld by Shutdown Leaves Economists Guessing
item.description: Policymakers will enter uncharted territory without employment data that the government is expected to withhold because of its shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: A Federal Shutdown May Be Imminent. How Would It Affect the Economy?
item.description: Congress and the White House have days to fund the government and avert a disruptive and potentially costly lapse in funding.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Spencer Pratt Lost His House in the Palisades Fire and Thinks Gavin Newsom Should Take the Blame
item.description: After losing his house in the Palisades fire, Spencer Pratt has gone from the archetype of celebrity emptiness to community activist — and become a magnet for Republican politicians.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty

item.title: A Tech Expo Shows What China Can Make, but Not Who’ll Buy It All
item.description: The vast Global Digital Trade Expo in Hangzhou stood as a rebuke to U.S. efforts to hem in China’s technology. But the real competition is internal, and profits are hard to find.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins

item.title: A.I. Fighter Jets and Cockroach Spies: Inside the Changing Business of War
item.description: Russia’s war on Ukraine changed the course of a generation of start-ups and investors that have applied a new business model to Europe’s military buildup.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Officials Flesh Out Tariffs on Kitchen Cabinets, Furniture and Timber
item.description: The White House set a relatively low tariff on imports of timber and lumber, and a significantly higher tariff on furniture and kitchen cabinets.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Expands Global Technology Net With Rules Covering Subsidiaries
item.description: The Trump administration issued a rule to automatically extend trade restrictions for organizations on the “entity list” to any majority-owned subsidiary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: H-1B Visas Have Problems. Trump’s $100,000 Fee Won’t Fix Them.
item.description: For years, proposals have circulated to stop abuse of the H-1B program. The Trump administration’s big changes largely ignored them.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Trump Expands Tariffs Beyond Supreme Court’s Reach
item.description: The president’s tariffs on foreign drugs and furniture rely on national security laws outside the scope of current lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Will Slap Tariffs on Imported Drugs, Trucks and Household Furnishings
item.description: The president said his tariffs would range from 25 to 100 percent and go into effect next week.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Rebecca Robbins and Peter Eavis

item.title: Giant Brand Bikes Made in Taiwan Barred by Trump Administration
item.description: The Trump administration said it would begin seizing Giant brand bicycles manufactured in Taiwan at the U.S. border, after an investigation found evidence of forced labor.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu

item.title: Princess Awesome vs. the United States of America
item.description: A children’s clothing company has become the face of a legal battle over President Trump’s trade policy, after years of struggling with the challenges of domestic manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alyssa Schukar

item.title: U.S. Pledges Support for Argentina’s Economy and Javier Milei
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said “all options” are under consideration to help President Javier Milei.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith

item.title: Trump’s Tax Cut Is Underwater. Can a ‘Refund Boom’ Save It?
item.description: Republicans are hoping a new name, along with larger refunds for many Americans next year, can buoy an economic agenda that polls show is unpopular.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: Europe Announces New Sanctions to Ramp Up Pressure on Russia
item.description: The latest set of European Union restrictions are aimed at chipping away at Russia’s energy profits and ability to do business globally.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Did Britain Win the Trade War? Why It’s Tough to Declare a Victor.
item.description: Popular products from Britain and the European Union show how uneven and unpredictable U.S. tariffs have become, even when part of trade deals.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson, Jeanna Smialek, Ani Matevosian and Lucia Calfapietra

item.title: Fed Cuts Rates for First Time This Year
item.description: The Federal Reserve lowered rates by a quarter point, but one governor voted for a bigger cut. Balancing persistent inflation and a weaker labor market was “a challenging situation,” the central bank chair said.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: G.O.P. Again Cedes Power on Tariffs to Avoid Crossing Trump
item.description: House Republicans extended a maneuver they engineered earlier in the year that effectively strips Congress of the power to disapprove of President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison

item.title: U.S. and China Reach ‘Framework’ for a TikTok Sale
item.description: Top economic officials met in Madrid for a second day, with deadlines looming on tariffs and a ban on TikTok in the United States if it is not sold by its Chinese owner, ByteDance.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and José Bautista

item.title: U.S. and China Resume Talks on Tariffs and TikTok
item.description: Economic officials meeting in Madrid are seeking to head off a November tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
